job_title: Adjunct Clinical Instructor (Nursing) in Brookfield, WI

review_title: Finding a new job after forced return
job_title: Home Office Associate-Full Time in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Smaller company that knows who you are, this is a nice perk. Remote work WAS a perk until recently.
cons: As simple as the headline says: for some reason execs are demanding our return to the office with no real reason other than they want to control us. We’ve been remote all this time and forcing this return is not fair when we’ve proven we can do this. They also are making how many days you have to come in based on location. You’re punished for living closer to the offices by being forced in more, which is absolutely absurd.

job_title: Home Office Associate-Full Time in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Managers tend to be understanding, leadership is often nice, and it’s great seeing things like diversity encouraged. In the last years, albeit mainly due to covid, they have gotten far better with flexibility and remote work options. Relocating to nicer offices than what they had before was great, and it’s great for the Milwaukee economy too.
cons: They have suddenly decided to force people into the office again regardless of work ethic or review. We’ve been remote for a long enough time to prove we’re responsible, so why are we being forced back? I’ve heard rumblings of people searching for new jobs already because of this choice. Feels patronizing and unnecessary, and I don’t blame people for being unhappy.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Helping students with their goals
cons: Micromanaged and constantly needing to keep up with numbers

review_title: Forcing into office, bad time policy
job_title: Home Office Associate-Full Time in Milwaukee, WI
pros: I enjoyed working remote since being hired.
cons: They are forcing us into office with zero reason. My work flow is being ruined and their policy for when you have to come in is discriminatory based on those that live in the city. If you live closer, your required to come in 2 days a week. Who lives closer? lower income people. Who comes in less? Those that live further away and make more. Looking for new work.

review_title: Company Has Allergies Towards Pro Development, Ethics and Morale!
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Oakbrook Terrace, IL
pros: After I resigned from the company earlier this year, I would have to say that the day to day business ventures allowed flexibility as far as time off and/or leave work if there was a family emergency. Additionally, I  was able to control my work flow so that I may take the time to build rapport with students and consult with team members on best practices within the admissions department to succeed on a continuous basis.
cons: In all of my professional working career following college, I have never worked  for an organization who spent more time being adamant about getting in as many students as possible regardless if rapport was implemented or not, along with retention strategies. Next, there was a wealth of favoritism from admissions management to specific advisors who either had a nice appearance, relationship/friendship  outside of the office, and/or perk promises. Then, over-promising on upper level management positions and under-delivering on seeing those come to fruition at the office. Lastly, senior level-management playing a below average interactive role by less 10% on the floor and more authoritative behind their executive desk when managing their reporting directors in what to dictate/distribute to the admissions team.

job_title: Systems Division Chair-General Education in Atlanta, GA
pros: Online Education great for working individual.
cons: No problems at all from me.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Oakbrook Terrace, IL
pros: There is not one single pro
cons: everything, micromanage. One manager knows absolutely nothing, the other is a micromanager and their manager does nothing but sends emails all day that says URGENT he knows  nothing never helps anyone

job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Akron, OH
pros: It was great to work for them
cons: None. Moved to other job

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: Friendly people to work for. Lots of advancement opportunities for young people fresh out of college. Allowed for some flexibility in scheduling but lots of overtime because of the monthly starts and not enough people to do all the work.
cons: Where to begin. Former management loaded up the management positions with young people right out of college, gave them mba's from their university and did not provide a true route of progression. Someone a year out of college is promoted while others with several years of experience would be only spuriously considered. They knew who they were going to promote before the position was ever posted. After the former management team completed this task and summarily dismissed many senior staff they too exited stage left, on to greener and richer pastures. From the sounds of more recent comments this has not worked out well. What you make up for in youthful enthusiasm, you've lost in experience and practical knowledge. Good job guys!

review_title: Omaha School of Massage and healthcare review, which is a Herzing University campus
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Instructor in Omaha, NE
pros: You get to teach a subject you hopefully love and are knowledgable about.
cons:
See other post.
Lack of full time availability
Lack of leadership
No guidance
To much freedom for incompetent instructors
Lack professionalism
Interview and hiring process is a joke
Let almost anyone teach
No organization
Students are clueless after pre enrollment/orientation

job_title: Director in Milwaukee, WI
pros: There are "some" really great people who care about students.  And, it's a great place to get some experience in the level higher than what you are actually qualified to perform.   The Online Campus President is fantastic.  He understands leadership and is a fantastic mentor.
cons: Short term thinking.  There is very little strategy and they don't give any one strategy enough time to actually work.  Apathy.  The vast majority of employees are apathetic towards their jobs and are completely disengaged; regardless of what the engagement survey says.  Lack of integrity.  Senior leadership doesn't understand the concept of accountability.  You will be blamed for doing what they've told you to do.  Also, campus presidents and VPs spend a great deal of time trying to gain advantage and pointing fingers at each other and other department heads.    Bias.  Be extremely careful with Human Resources.  Make friends with the Director otherwise you will be targeted.  People. They don't care about you. You will be paid significantly less than what you are worth.  Find a job some where you can actually grow and succeed.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Amazing team to work with, great pay and great department chairs!  I've never felt afraid to come to my superiors for help or to voice a concern.  My dept chair goes to bat for her instructions. Fellow instructors are very kind to each other and help each other. Very supportive team.
cons: Nobody leaves so it makes it difficult to move up in the organization. Also, you can't work for two different departments at the same time. If you teach in one department, you can't teach a class on another department even if you have experience or credentials. A lot of professional development requirements.

review_title: Good place to get experience, move on
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Sincere attempts to create friendly workplace atmosphere, friendly coworkers, opportunities to learn (on the job, natch), opportunities to advance. I can recommend it if you know what you're getting into, and have an exit plan from the start.
cons:
Bad location (Menomonee falls) given young workforce. Extremely poor executive level decision making and communication.
Takes way too long to get approval for even small decisions

job_title: Associate Director in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: The people that work at HU Online are unbelievable. They work hard, and the truly care about the students. There is a good sense of community on the campus, and people in general like their coworkers. I enjoyed working with all of the departments on campus. We oftened shared lunch together, or got together after work.
cons: The management under which I worked was not positive.I was not given any training or guidance when hired into a management role. I worked very, very long hours (70hours/week) with no overtime. I have been told it has since changed with a new group of administrators!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milwaukee, WI
pros: The instructors are very nice and knowledgeable about their field.  The administrative teams and education departments genuinely care about their students and employees.
cons: This is one of the least organized schools I have ever worked for.  There are few policies and procedures that are standard throughout the company, which makes it difficult to work with multiple campuses.  On the campus level, the people are wonderful, but the lack of organization makes it a nightmare at times to work for.

review_title: Great place to work if you love helping people get an education.
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Milwaukee, WI
pros:
Being able to talk to people all over the country and helping them find the right college program is an awesome experience.  If you're a good advisor who truly cares about your students, then it is very rewarding.  You can actually help potential students to plan for their future career.  People call in with an end-goal, but they may have the wrong idea of how to get there.  You get the benefit of being able to change their life by helping them choose the right path to go where they want to go.  It is enriching.

The education offered by the school is one you can stand behind.  This isn't a fly-by-night online college that doesn't actually care.  The classes are not easy; they are just right.  Because the school started out (and remains) a physical campus, there is a long history for the institution that you can also stand proud about.  The owner/president/founding family is involved, which is wonderful. 

There is an open floor to speak to higher up people if you want to. 

Compensation is very good, or at least it was when I worked there.  Hard-work pays off.

Room for advancement early on. 

Ability to have fun and be creative with your team.
cons:
Some high up people in the HR department were awful and condescending, which was very troublesome if you did need to go to HR (which usually isn't necessary). 

There was a push to move towards hardcore education sales, so much so that some advisors were knowingly pushing through people who they knew they were setting up for failure. 

Forced group "fun" activities were sometimes daunting. 

Frequent changes of teams were meant to promote a broader connection to co-workers, but it really resulted in chaos and stress when having to pack up and learn how to deal with all new people ever 6 months (just when you had developed a good rapport with the last team).

job_title: Financial Aid in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: Ability to leave in emergencies, and some benefits are great.
cons: Lack of professional development opportunities, poor communication between upper management and the front lines, and favoritism of certain employees. If you end up working here, don't be afraid to move on. It won't get better.

job_title: Student Services in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Herzing is a friendly, feel good organization that genuinely cares about their employees and takes steps to make sure they are happy both personally and professionally.  It has more of a family feel than a corporate feel and the Herzing family treat their employees and students like extended family.
cons: Be prepared to work hard.  Herzing Online is a very busy place with high expectations and a fast pace; our focus is centered around student satisfaction and quality outcomes.  Those that excel in this environment are promoted quickly and thrive at Herzing.

job_title: Associate Professor in Oviedo, FL
pros: Good benefits and salary, good courses. Faculty have some input on curriculum. Love the premise of increasing access for a diverse workforce.
cons: Terrible leadership with fast faculty turnover. Mandated changes every single term with no regard for students, or evidenced-base practice.  New program chair is a tyrant with no experience and calls everyone baby girl, sweetie, honey. Reported numerous times with no repercussions.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Oakbrook Terrace, IL
pros:
Some good employees and management
Work from home was good while it lasted, (for about a month)
Fun Admissions Retreat- They actually had the meeting in Milwaukee, WI one year. (Sarcasm). Good time to meet every Advisor for the Univ in person.
cons:
No growth opportunities- Hired as an Admissions Advisor, stuck as an Admissions Advisor, unless you're lucky enough to move laterally as an EC- but be careful. Don't let them force you to do two jobs while being paid for one. 

Awful schedule/hours

You're not even as good as your last start. All they want to know is what you can do for them NOW

Bad schedule- If you're scheduled to work on a Sunday, your hours are: 1030-7. who wants to wrk those hours on a Sunday?!?!

Mgmt will ALWAYS find something you're not doing well enough. If you have a good start, you're low on transfers. If you're high on transfers, you're low on interviews and your transfer to interview held conversation ratio is too low. 

No such thing as a, "perfect interview", or score- Mgmt will rate you  lower scorewise and nitpick what you didn't  do well enough on an interview.

Cheap company. Couldn't even spring for coffee stirrers. 

Mgmt favors tenured employees. There were certain employees who were there for wayyyy too long, but bc they, "started" the office w/the DOA, they were still employed. It didn't matter that they said controversial things OUT LOUD. Seemed like they had the freedom to say whatever they wanted, whenever they wanted, w/no consequences. How does that promote a good culture?!?! Good employees left, bad ones stayed. 

Useless weekly WIG meetings- They were a waste of time.

job_title: Enrollment Management in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: Flexible scheduling and mostly friendly staffers. A bit young. Mostly just out of school so they could get them cheap, but they don't stay.
cons: Management promoted based on favoritism not work, skills, training or education. One person could get away with something (i.e. 'socializing') while several others would be dinged for it. It all depended on who liked you and who didn't, if they even bothered to know you at all.

review_title: Nice culture, company is run like a small business, a bit behind the times
job_title: in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Upper management really does seem to care and the environment is pleasant and respectful. Co-workers are a friendly group and everyone really tries to carry their weight.
cons: Salaries and benefits are less than other for-profit educational companies in the area. Too much casualness leads to favoritism and the wrong people getting promotions. This has negatively affected morale. The company's intentions are good, but they need to increase the professionalism of their managers and standardize and oversee management practices more.

job_title: in Milwaukee, WI
pros:
The benefits are OK.  Nothing spectacular but average to slightly above average - vacation time is good.
Yearly bonus of a couple hundred bucks.
There's a decent "community" among employees.
cons:
Very low pay compared to same job in other industries.
The whole private for profit industry is shady.
Stressful work when dealing with regulatory and compliance issues with short deadlines.

job_title: Marketing Project Management in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: Self direction of workflow completion, Variety of daily work, Dress code using company logo clothing, Generally positive coworker attitudes and team efforts on getting projects completed.
cons:
Not as much organization as I would like for smooth workflow processing.
Not having a solid senior management positions "game face" to relay on for a solid line on which to structure company confidence, across all senior management positions

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Birmingham, AL
pros: I really can say how much I enjoyed my local Herzing family but also the teams at each office. They worked very hard and keeping us all informed from the home campus to each individual office. They offer diversified programs at varying costs to fit a person's budget and career needs. We each took time to interview students and really got to know them and what they needed in terms of a program. The folks that work here really care about your well being as a student and your success.
cons: I wish we could have more time to volunteer within the local community.

review_title: There are worse ways to Work...

cons: Lots of re-organization and changing strategies, moving management around, and uncertainty of job duties.  Executives make high salaries, but the entry level position salaries are very low, and the hours can be inconvenient.
